questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -

You have an Azure subscription that contains a virtual network. The virtual network contains two subnets named Subnet1 and Subnet2. You have an instance of Azure Application Gateway v2 named AppGw1 that is connected to Subnet1.

You need to move AppGw1 to Subnet2. The solution must minimize downtime.

What should you do? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
{ChatGPT}
Set the frontend IP address type to:
Both

Reason: Ensuring that the Application Gateway supports both public and private IP addresses helps maintain connectivity during the transition.
Before moving AppGw1, run:
Stop-AzApplicationGateway

Reason: You must stop the Application Gateway before reconfiguring or moving it to another subnet.
To move AppGw1, run:
Set-AzApplicationGateway

Reason: This command is used to apply the necessary changes, including reconfiguring the subnet association of the Application Gateway.

Correct. AGv2 may have only public IP. You can move the AG only within a VNET:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/application-gateway/application-gateway-faq#can-i-change-the-virtual-network-or-subnet-for-an-existing-application-gateway

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -

You have an Azure subscription that contains a virtual network named VNet1.

You need to deploy an instance of Azure Application Gateway v2 named AppGw1 to VNet1. AppGw1 will include one basic listener and two multi-site listeners. The listeners will be accessible only from VNet1.

What is the minimum number of IP addresses required for AppGw1? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Public IP: 1 -------When configuring at Portal, it tells Application GW SKU Standard-V2 dont support only private ip addresses as the frontend.
Private IP:1 (only need to add multiple routing rules(combo of listener settings )

You need three private IP addresses - one for the Application Gateway and one for each listener (basic and multisite)
No need for Public IP Address

With AGW v2, it must use Public IP address. If you select only (Private IP address) for "Frontend IP address type", it will show the following error message:
"Application Gateways with a tier of Standard_v2 don’t support only private IP addresses as the frontend. Supported SKU tiers are standard and WAF."
Thus, at least one Public IP address is required for AGWv2.
Its possible to assigned multi listeners to the same Private IP address as log as they are using different ports.
So, suggested answers is: (1 Public IP) and (1 Private IP).

Looks like the question is incorrect because "Application Gateway V2 SKU doesn't support an internal IP address as it's only frontend".
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-network/ip-services/configure-public-ip-application-gateway

Public IP :0
Private IP:1

Keyword: "accessible only from VNet1"

No need public IP: 0
Private IP: 1 is enough for Application Gateway

Selected Answer: A
Public IP 0, OK but, Shouldn't the private IP be 1 only?
the question is speaking about the minimum number of IP addresses required for AppGw1 and not the minimum number of IP for the AppGw1.. 
I've seen a lot of internal APPGW with single private IP and different single/multisite listeners ...

comments.content:
ahh I was tired, sorry I meant 
the question is speaking about the minimum number of IP addresses required for AppGw1 and not the minimum number of IPs required for the listeners
I think one private IP is enough...
What do you think?

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -

You have an Azure subscription that contains an Azure application gateway named AG1 and two Azure App Service apps named App1 and App2 that have the following configurations:

• Both apps are accessible by using HTTP and HTTPS.
• HTTP host headers are used to route requests to the appropriate apps.
• Both apps are hosted in a single App Service Environment in the West Europe Azure region.

You need to publish the apps by using AG1. The solution must ensure that AG1 provides both HTTP and HTTPS access.

What is the minimum number of resources required for AG1? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Public IP addresses: 1 (for Azure application gateway AG1)
Listeners: 2 (1 for HTTP and 1 for HTTPS)
Backend pools: 2 (1 for each of Azure App Service apps App1 and App2)

1 Public IP
4 Listeners (2 per App, http and https) One listerner per protocol and app, total 4 listeners
2 BE pool

1 Public IP
4 listeners: 2 apps by 2 (http and https)
2 backend pools for 2 different apps

comments.content:
Correction:
1 Public IP
2 listeners (http and https) with multiple rules
2 backend pools for 2 different apps

discussion.content: Given answers are correct

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have an Azure application gateway that has Azure Web Application Firewall (WAF) enabled.
You configure the application gateway to direct traffic to the URL of the application gateway.
You attempt to access the URL and receive an HTTP 403 error. You view the diagnostics log and discover the following error.
//IMG//

You need to ensure that the URL is accessible through the application gateway.
Solution: You disable the WAF rule that has a ruleId 920300.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
CORRECT ANSWER.
correct answer
in exam 4jan23

Selected Answer: A
A. Yes
disable the WAF rule that has a ruleId 920300
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/application-gateway/application-gateway-diagnostics#firewall-log
Value
action
 
Description
Action taken on the request. Available values are Blocked and Allowed (for custom rules), Matched (when a rule matches a part of the request), and Detected and Blocked (these are both for mandatory rules, depending on if the WAF is in detection or prevention mode).
Matched for blocking that can be disabled ,while blocking for rules that can't be disabled "builtin"
A correct Answer. Disabling the WAF Rule implies not match required for " specified header string"
Appeared in exam on 17/01/2022
Not on exam 1/6/2022

comments.content: No - the action is well stated. The action is Blocked when it reaches the max anomaly count and trigger the non-disabled rule, from that rule you will see action "Blocked"

discussion.content: To be more precise, the action should be stated as "Blocked" rather "Matched" for accuracy purposes.

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription that contains an Azure App Service app. The app uses a URL of https://www.contoso.com.
You need to use a custom domain on Azure Front Door for www.contoso.com. The custom domain must use a certificate from an allowed certification authority
(CA).
What should you include in the solution?

choices.A: an enterprise application in Azure Active Directory (Azure AD)

comments.content: Your own certificate means the certificate is issued by a CA.

discussion.content:
Correct, use Key Vault with your own certificate 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/frontdoor/front-door-custom-domain-https#option-2-use-your-own-certificate

Selected Answer: C
The correct answer is C, but the explanation is - you must create a complete certificate chain with an allowed certificate authority (CA) that is part of the Microsoft Trusted CA List. And Azure Key Vault allows you to store your certificates securely. Azure Front Door uses this secure mechanism to get your certificate (Self Signed or CA Provided) and it requires a few extra steps. 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/frontdoor/front-door-custom-domain-https#option-2-use-your-own-certificate

Selected Answer: C
C is correct and how can i get this one WRONG!! no way considering i just finished 20 of them at work!!

Selected Answer: C
Keyvault is the correct answers as noted in the official docs

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/frontdoor/front-door-custom-domain-https
on exam today
Appeared on exam 6/28/22
Appeared on exam 6/27/2022

Selected Answer: C
C. Azure Key Vault
This question was on the exam on 18th Feb 2022.
Azure Key Vault is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
Azure Key Vault is the correct answer
Came on exam 28/Jan/22
on exam 1/6/2022 - Order is different.

Option 2
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/frontdoor/front-door-custom-domain-https
AZURE KEY VAULT.

C - Azure Key Vault is the correct answer. 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/frontdoor/front-door-custom-domain-https
